Topic.Title: huge open interest on 13 calls, we'll see!

Message.Msg: - It's a Laffer Curve actually. With the demand and supply of call options determined by the probability or improbability of the calls expiring Worthless. If the probability of the closest-to-the-money calls expiring Worthless is 100%, time after time, then the demand for nvda calls approaches zero. 'Cause it's no fun to keep losing your hard-earned cash on Worthless nvda call options, time after time. Note however, that the demand for nvda calls might not actually reach zero, since there is always a new crop of turnip-heads that are naive and think they can make money on that rigged game of nvda calls. Those folks are called the Laffer call buyers. HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA! -

Topic.Title: Google halts 16gb Nexus 7 new order: demand too hot

Message.Msg: http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/2012/jul/22/google-nexus-7-16-surprise

Topic.Title: Google halts 16gb Nexus 7 new order: demand too hot

Message.Msg: - Google halts new orders for 16GB Nexus 7, surprised by demand Heavy demand for the 16GB version of the new Nexus 7 tablet has caught Google out after it expected more customers ordering through Google Play to want the 8GB version Charles Arthur | guardian.co.uk | Sunday 22 July 2012 07.48 EDT In excerpts. Google's Nexus 7 16GB version is now Unvailable through its Play Store. Sources close to Google say the search giant seriously underestimated the demand for the 16GB version of its 7in Nexus 7 tablet, which has sold out from stockists and other sources while demand for the smaller 8GB version remains comparatively low. The company has now Halted further orders of the 16GB version of the tablet, costing £199, on its Google Play store in the US and UK. While the 8GB model, which costs £159, is shown as "in stock" and being delivered in 3-5 business days, the 16GB version only offers an option to "sign up to be notified by email" when it becomes available. The 8GB version is only being sold through Google's own store, rather than physical retailers - but online buyers appear to have Shunned it, surprising Google, which had thought that the cheaper version, despite having only half as much storage, would sell better than it has. The Guardian understands that Google's planners had thought that buyers on the Google Play store, more than from physical or online retailers, would be more committed to the company's "cloud" concept, and so would have more of their content stored online, rather than wanting to keep it on the device. But most buyers appear to have noted that the storage on the device cannot be upgraded and decided to get the larger model. Asus is believed to be ramping up production of another batch of models, but that could take some weeks to arrive. The Nexus 7 marks Google's first foray into the tablet business. The device is made to Google's specifications by Asus; the 8GB version is being sold almost at cost ($199 compared to the build cost of $157), according to estimates by IHS iSuppli. The 16GB version is more profitable for Google." So Google continues to blow-out the remaining 8GB version, for which "demand remains comparatively low", -- and on which Google makes almost nothing. While orders for the slightly more profitable 16GB version have been Halted. They have to be absolutely laughing their heads off, right? At 1 Infinite Loop, Cupertino, CA. -

Topic.Title: Google halts 16gb Nexus 7 new order: demand too hot

Message.Msg: msft, if they are smart, which they are not, as witnesses by their going 'exotic' on their tablets while the whole world + dog have already gone cheap, can have a winner for windoz that more than justifies the cost over free, if their tablet can readily vpn back into home networks. Work data, I couldn't care less where that is stored on. Private data.... that shall always remain private. But msft will never do that, they are under the mistaken belief that they need to make you use their clouds. Same for goog - the 8G raison d'être is for you to use their cloud, as if we haven,t lost enough of our privacy already in this digital world of facebooks and tweeters and governments scanning all emails and online communications. Now if somebody like logmein will bring out an app to do this, they will make a lot of money.

Topic.Title: ACER Iconia A110 reaches FCC (Tegra 3 on board)

Message.Msg: think the winning formula is 8G on board to keep the price low, but add microSD slot for expandability. But then, you'll miss out on the added $50 charge for $4 of 8G nand...... would be a good strategy for somebody like amzn or even goog who are more interested to selling their machines than making 10% on the hardware. don't look to any of the Asian guys to have half a million on hand at launch/'build up their production capacity'. They ain't that foolish to risk $500M a throw like HP and RIMM found out the hard way when they rolled snake-eyes. as I've been saying, no socket in THE two of the hottest names in mobile, nvda is just throwing $100M/Q for the table scraps. big hit on nexus, htc 1 X, all that does is to reduce the quarterly loss from $100M/Q to $90M/Q. That's far out of whack the whole tegra project is. To all those who keep bashing qcom and aapl, I'll give you a what-if: what if qcom's lament about 28nm availability is aapl needed to hold up releasing their quad core iPhone5 so much because they both are waiting for enough 28nm qcom cheap radios. Not so easy to have 20M or more of those on hand at launch..... that's >>10x Nexus
